wordpressPost.title: Employee Engagement Weekly News Roundup: 3/27/2015
wordpressPost.content:
The WeSpire Employee Engagement Weekly News Roundup aggregates the top employee engagement articles from around the industry to keep you informed and inspire positive impact in your organization.

Companies Are Spending More on Corporate Wellness Programs but Employees Are Leaving Millions on the Table

Fidelity Investments and the National Business Group on Health conducted a survey on wellness programs and the results reveal that employers will spend an average of $693 per employee on wellness-based incentives in 2015, up from $594 in 2014. However, the research found that fewer than half (47%) of employees earned their full incentive amount in 2014. The challenge now rests in the hands of companies to find ways to increase participation through tools and innovative technology.

Top 10 states with highest, lowest employee engagement

According to a new gallup survey, people in Montana, Mississippi, and Louisiana. are the most actively engaged workers in America. The survey, conducted by phone interviews, sought to determine the most engaged and unengaged states. Not surprisingly, a lot had to do with economic opportunity of the home state.

Behavioral Science can Boost motivation

The Chartered Institute of Personnel and Development conducted a study and found that money is not always the best way of motivating employees. Most interestingly, the report found that by evolving the reward structure, organizations can take more control over factors that determine employees’ motivation. This research shows that investments in applied behavior science can help to shape and affect employee motivation.

Thinking Differently on Engagement

Deloitte’s third annual Global Human Capital Trends report released this week finds 87% of HR and business leaders across the world identify employee engagement as a top concern ‘ increasing 8 percentage points from last year. What this means for managers and organizations: it’s time to re-think how we manage people.
